data.title: atom -v not working in Cron Job
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/

    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

[Description of the issue]
If I use atom -v at the CLI it works as expected
If I run the Script by hand In CLI it works as expected
If I run the Cron Job from System Settings it works as suspected
But if it is running automatically by Cron there is no output The String is completely empty.
There are no error messages at all
Could it be that there is no gui in the running Cron Job?

### Steps to Reproduce

1. [First Step]
2. [Second Step]
3. [and so on...]

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
print the atom Version info

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Empty String
**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%
### Versions

all
actually on
Atom    : 1.20.0-dev-5a8dce1
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.
Kubuntu 16.04 LTS
By the Way, for apm it works.

data.title: Option Clear Window State after Multiple Hangs (Proposal)
data.body:
### Description

I just had an issue where my atom hangs due to a window state that was unstable, which causes it to freeze. Opening new directories of atom works fine, but as soon as I open the same directory, it hangs again. I was able to fix it by running `atom --clear-window-state` , however for non tech savvy users they would have to probably go through a reinstall. Perhaps this could be an option that could appear if a user attempts to re-open atom multiple times with the same directory?

### Versions

Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 ia32
python
git
visual studio 2015

data.title: Ensure custom title bar is always updated when document.title changes
data.body:
This pull-request uses a new private API on Workspace that emits an event every time the window title gets updated (e.g. as a result of an active pane item changing, the project paths changing, etc.).

This fixes a bug that left the custom title bar with a stale `document.title` under some circumstances.

üçê'ed with @jasonrudolph.

/cc: @atom/maintainers

data.title: (German) Umlauts in file path break file opening
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/

    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If you open a file or a project folder which has (German) umlauts, like √Ñ, √ñ, √ú in it, text files opened will alway be empty

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a folder called B√§ume (or any other folder containing umlauts).
2. Create test.txt file and open with Editor.
3. Write random word or sentence in it.
4. Open file or folder with Atom
5. File appears empty.

**Expected behavior:** File should be opened correctly

**Actual behavior:** File is empty

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.0-beta1
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

### Additional Information

Atom running on Windows 10 Pro (Creator Update)

data.title: Fix measuring block decorations if adding them before attaching element
data.body:
Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14817.

Previously, when a block decoration needed measurements, we would always honor that request, even when the `blockDecorationMeasurementsArea` had not been explicitly sized yet, or when its size was not up-to-date. This was causing decorations to be incorrectly measured, due to a problem similar to #14769.

This pull-request fixes the above issue by flushing the newly measured scroll width to the measurement area (if needed) before measuring block decorations.

/cc: @atom/maintainers @t9md

data.title: Fix resetting styles in NodePool
data.body:
Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14842.

Previously, we were mistakenly not clearing out some styling properties like `marginTop`, thus causing e.g. line numbers to be misaligned. This was caused by manual updates to an element's style object, without a consequent update to the `NodePool`.

With this pull-request we will now rely on `element.styleMap` (a DOM primitive) to detect which styles have been set on a element that is about to be recycled and, if the object being created doesn't use them, simply clear them out.

data.title: git checkout new_branch,the resource manager list content is delayed
data.body: In a git project, when the branch is switched, the resource manager list content is delayed and the refresh is sometimes invalid

data.title: Fixed the path for invalid reference, when copying resource.
Build failed when i try to build on windows 7 using script/build` script
data.body:
### Prerequisites

- [x] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
 - [x] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
 - [x] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
 - [x] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=‚úì&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
 - [x] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
Build failed when i try to build on windows 7 using script/build` script

### #Steps to Reproduce

1. go to the `{atom}/script/' directory on windows
2. type the `build` command and execute it.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
- build success

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
```
Œª build
Node:   v6.10.3
Npm:    v3.10.5
Python: v2.7.13
Installing script dependencies
Installing apm
Installing modules done
Wrote Dependencies Fingerprint: F:\Home\atom\node_modules\.dependencies-fingerprint 522e392629c5debc77902c467346d6823fdcd4b1
Cleaning F:\Home\atom\out
Copying assets to F:\Home\atom\out\app
Transpiling packages with custom transpiler configurations in F:\Home\atom\out\app
 transpiling for package github
Installing modules done
Transpiling Babel paths in F:\Home\atom\out\app
Transpiling CoffeeScript paths in F:\Home\atom\out\app
Transpiling CSON paths in F:\Home\atom\out\app
Transpiling PEG.js paths in F:\Home\atom\out\app
Generating module cache for F:\Home\atom\out\app
Generating pre-built less cache in F:\Home\atom\out\app\less-compile-cache
Generating metadata for F:\Home\atom\out\app\package.json
Generating API docs at F:\Home\atom\docs\output\atom-api.json
Skipping symbol dumping because minidump is not supported on Windows
Running electron-packager on F:\Home\atom\out\app with app name "atom"
Packaging app for platform win32 x64 using electron v1.6.9
Copying non-ASAR resources to F:\Home\atom\out\Atom x64\resources
Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, stat 'F:\Home\atom\script\resources\win\atom.cmd'
  at Error (native)
  at Object.fs.statSync (fs.js:1000:11)
  at Object.statSync (F:\Home\atom\script\node_modules\graceful-fs\polyfills.js:297:22)
  at Object.copySync (F:\Home\atom\script\node_modules\fs-extra\lib\copy-sync\copy-sync.js:21:84)
  at forEach.file (F:\Home\atom\script\lib\package-application.js:76:27)
  at Array.forEach (native)
  at copyNonASARResources (F:\Home\atom\script\lib\package-application.js:76:8)
  at runPackager.then (F:\Home\atom\script\lib\package-application.js:50:12)


```

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
- 100% (when i try to build on windows, always occurred.)

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.
```
apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 ia32
python 2.7.13
git 2.9.3.windows.1
visual studio 2015
windows 7
atom source target version:  5a8dce117541bef77d3b8404dbc55383cb278f16
```

### Additional Information
I fixed the build script at {atom}/build/lib/package-application.js:74, following

**path.join('resources', 'win', file) => path.join(CONFIG.repositoryRootPath, 'resources', 'win', file)**

**Current version**
```
  } else if (process.platform === 'win32') {
    [ 'atom.cmd', 'atom.sh', 'atom.js', 'apm.cmd', 'apm.sh', 'file.ico', 'folder.ico' ]
      .forEach(file => fs.copySync(path.join('resources', 'win', file), path.join(bundledResourcesPath, 'cli', file)))
  }
```

**Modified version**
```
  } else if (process.platform === 'win32') {
    [ 'atom.cmd', 'atom.sh', 'atom.js', 'apm.cmd', 'apm.sh', 'file.ico', 'folder.ico' ]
       .forEach(file => fs.copySync(path.join(CONFIG.repositoryRootPath, 'resources', 'win', file), path.join(bundledResourcesPath, 'cli', file)))
  }
```

so then, solved the above issue.

data.title: Problem with the new Git Integration in Atom 1.18 (32-bit)
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
* [ ] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
* [X] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
* [X] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=‚úì&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
* [X] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The new Git Integration in Atom does not work on my computer, probably since the 1.18 version.

### Steps to Reproduce & Actual behavior:

1. Run 1.18.0 ia32; open project/directory that uses git VCS. *Note: The git repository has been properly initialized long ago and git seamlessly used for the project since then.*
2. The `.git` subdirectory can be seen in the seen in the Treeview - `Project` Tab/Pane. The files/folders have correct colors according to their git VCS state (black/green/dark-orange). The branch name is not displayed in the statusbar, as it used to be in the previous versions of Atom. However, the correct branch name can be seen in statusbar for the very short moment when starting Atom before the Atom's GUI gets fully initialized.
3. The `Create repository` button is present in the `Git` Tab/Pane. After clicking on that button the Error popup appears.
```
Unable to initialize git repository in /home/SOME_PATH_HERE_EDITED/006_sandbox

/opt/atom/resources/app/node_modules/dugite/git/bin/git: 1:
/opt/atom/resources/app/node_modules/dugite/git/bin/git:
Syntax error: Unterminated quoted string
```
4. The `Git` Tab/Pane is somewhat blank, see screenshot. There definitely are modified-unstaged files in the project folder, also the modified-staged files; these can be seen in system terminal via `git status` command. These files are not displayed in the Git Tab/Pane in the Atom editor. The `Commit` button is disabled. 
![atom-git](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22847930/27520461-816770ac-5a0c-11e7-9f63-9d0a5db0999a.png)
*Note: screenshot taken when Atom running in safe-mode.*

**Reproduces how often:** Always. Tested with multiple directories/projects using Git VCS. When Atom is used for the project/directory that actually is not the git repository (`git init` never ran in the directory; `.git` subdirectory not present in the directory), the steps 3 and 4 can also be reproduced in Atom.

### Versions
```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

$ apm --version
apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 ia32
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4
```
Ubuntu 16.04 32-bit
Linux 4.4.0-81-generic i686 GNU/Linux

### Additional info

Because the issue has not yet been reported, I suspect the issue could be 32-bit related only or very specific.

data.title: Add instructions for local development
data.body:
### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

### Description of the Change

Finding out how to contribute to my first Atom package was problematic
and took me quite some time to figure out how to locally run the packages.
There were some spread out answers in the Atom discussion forum,
but I think it is easier for new developers to read the CONTRIBUTING guide
instead of using Google to find out how to contribute.

### Alternate Designs

Right now it is only on the Atom discussion forum, not in the contributing guide.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

All Atom packages link to this contributing guide.

### Benefits

Developers who have not contributed just yet are now more easily able to find out how to develop local changes and contribute them :)

### Possible Drawbacks

None that I am aware of, more sentences? :open_mouth: 

### Applicable Issues

N/A

data.title: Tree View Not Collapsing
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

### Description

[Description of the issue]
The tree view of the panel does not collapse,
the button "collapse" "extend" does not do anything, the treeview stays there.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Click the "Collapse button" for the Tree view
2. Resize the window automatically using ( win key + right arrow)

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
I expect the tree view to collapse so the "code" panel 

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

The tree view stays there, even though i click the collapse button

### Versions
atom: 1.18.0
electron: 1.3.15
node: 6.5.0

### Additional Information
windows 10

data.title: Return true from Pane#destroyItem if item is destroyed
data.body:
This PR ensures that we return the correct boolean value from `Pane.prototype.destroyItem` when the `force` parameter is `true` or the item should not prompt to save. 

Without this, logic such as the following 
```
const destroyed = await pane.destroyItem(item); // returns the value of `item.destroy && item.destroy()` which can be undefined or null
if (!destroyed) {
  pane.activateItem(item); // called on an item that has been destroyed
}
```
... produces an uncaught error error ...
```
Uncaught (in promise) Error: Adding a pane item with URI '/some/path/to/item' that has already been destroyed
```

/cc @maxbrunsfeld for relevant change made in https://github.com/atom/atom/commit/dc320181fc852f3174411e107bfd2a02f2c504ad#diff-1a7d1dda35d8e7ed3ad35b9a9fd2f134L615

NOTE: Fix needs to be cherry-picked to beta on the `1.9-releases` branch in order for [`atom/github` CI](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/Atom/github/branch/master/job/igsd6yot0wjimv48/tests) to pass

data.title: Atom Simply Not Working
data.body:
I went to log into atom today and this is what my terminal looks like:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19434960/27492331-ba402a18-57fa-11e7-99c9-8e0c084656b1.png)

Can someone please let me know how to fix this or what would have caused it. This is the second time this has happened in the last month. I can't do anything in Atom, it won't even let me access the settings!

data.title: Upgraded to Debian 9 - libX11.so.6: undefined symbol: xcb_wait_for_reply64
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=‚úì&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

After upgrading from Debian 8 to Debian 9, I'm not able anymore to start Atom.  
I'm getting this message:  
```
/usr/share/atom/atom --executed-from=/home/kody/dev --pid=9770: symbol lookup error: /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libX11.so.6: undefined symbol: xcb_wait_for_reply64
```

Same results with `--safe`.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Upgrade to Debian 9 and upgrade all packages.
2. Start Atom and get an error in the console.

**Expected behavior:** Atom would open its main window.

**Actual behavior:** Atom doesn't start.

**Reproduces how often:** Everytime.

### Versions

```
$ atom --version

$ apm --version
apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.11.0

$ uname -a
Linux remote 4.4.19-1-pve #1 SMP Wed Sep 14 14:33:50 CEST 2016 x86_64 GNU/Linux

$ lsb_release -a
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID:	Debian
Description:	Debian GNU/Linux 9.0 (stretch)
Release:	9.0
Codename:	stretch
```

FYI, I used the latest `.deb` from the website, Atom 1.18.0.

### Additional Information

I tried to remove both `libx11-dev` and `atom` with apt, then install back `libx11-dev` (`apt install libx11-dev`) and atom (`dpkg -i atom*.deb`). This didn't change anything.

data.title: Indentation of large number of lines is very very slow.
data.body:
Hi,

One of my files has about 500 lines and the average length of these lines are about 40 characters. I opened this file and tried to use command+] to indent all the lines. The latency (delay) is very significant (around 1 second) compared to sublime, or even VScode. 

Then I opened a larger file containing 2000 lines and I indented it the same way. The delay is increasing significantly. 

I'm just wondering whether this drawback can be solved and the performance can be improved or not. Thanks.

data.title: The editor has crashed when try to open .psd file

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * [X] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode

    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The editor has crashed when open `.psd` file.

**Reproduces how often:** always

### Versions

1.19.0-beta1

### Additional Information

I didn't encounter this in earlier versions. It opened and showed a character set.
As a suggestion: may be Atom could open `.psd` file as an image like `.png` or `.jpg`?
